risinfo.booktitle: Companion Animal End of Life Care for the Veterinary Technician

para.emphasis: Veterinary Technology Program, Dalhousie University, Bible Hill, NS, Canada

sect2.title: 2.1 Introduction
sect2.para: Pain assessment is an important part of the veterinary technician's role in companion animal end‐of‐life (EOL) care. Before pain can be managed, it must be recognized and characterized. Technicians well versed in recognizing and assessing pain serve as advocates to improve their patient’s quality of life (QOL). They communicate with the veterinarian to inform treatment plans, administer care to the patient, and educate caregivers regarding the assessment and impact of pain in their pet.

Assessing pain in animals is challenging primarily due to their inability to directly communicate the type, severity, and duration of pain to their caregivers and veterinary team. This is further complicated by the fact that animals have evolved to hide pain and weakness as a safety mechanism against potential threats. These barriers can prevent caregivers from providing a full history of the onset and impact of pain and may obscure the technician’s assessment of pain. Effective education and training allow technicians to overcome some of these challenges. This chapter will summarize current information on pain assessment in companion animals, but technicians must also routinely engage in continuing education to ensure they are providing the most informed and up‐to‐date care possible.

sect2.title: 2.2 The Physiology and Classification of Pain
sect2.para: To effectively recognize and assess pain, technicians must first understand nociception which is the physiological process through which the body senses and interprets pain. Nociception is complex and is influenced by multiple factors including the type, duration, and frequency of sensory input. These factors impact the experience of pain for the animal and the clinical presentation to the observer assessing pain. For example, chronic pain presents differently than acute pain, and inflammatory pain (e.g. osteoarthritis) presents differently than pain caused by acute tissue trauma (e.g. bone fracture).

sect2.para: Nociception consists of four steps: transduction, transmission, modulation, and perception (Figure 2.1) ch0012-c2-bib-0001. These steps can be impacted by medical and nursing interventions that will be discussed in Chapter 3.

listitem.para: Transduction begins when a noxious stimulus is detected by sensory receptors. The stimulus can be thermal, chemical, or mechanical.
Transmission is the relay of the stimulus from sensory receptors, through afferent nerve fibers and to the spinal cord.

Modulation of the nerve impulse describes the alteration of the signal at the level of the spinal cord. This effect can be excitatory or inhibitory in nature, thus acting to amplify or suppress the stimulus on its path to the brain.
Perception occurs when the nerve impulse reaches the brain and there is a conscious awareness of the pain stimulus.

sect2.para: Pain is a normal, adaptive physiological process that functions to protect the animal from further harm. If a dog injures a joint while playing fetch, the pain may cause them to limp. This pain and the favoring of the limb limits weight‐bearing on the injury, which helps to prevent further damage while the healing process begins. Maladaptive pain is a pathological process that occurs when pain continues beyond the expected period of healing and is no longer serving a protective functionch0012-c2-bib-0002. Pain of significant intensity or prolonged duration can lead to changes in the nociceptive pathways that become “sensitized” to pain, a state known as neuropathic pain .

The presentation and impact of pain in EOL patients can and will change over time. Correctly identifying and classifying the pain a patient is experiencing allows veterinary teams to intervene with appropriate analgesia. Pain can be characterized by the underlying cause (i.e. traumatic tissue damage, inflammation, neoplasia, etc.), severity, bodily location (somatic or visceral), and its duration (acute or chronic).

sect2.title: 2.2.1 Somatic and Visceral Pain
sect2.para: Somatic pain occurs with tissue damage in the musculoskeletal system or the skin and associated structures. Any insult or injury to these structures may cause somatic pain (i.e. sharp or blunt trauma, chemical or thermal damage, etc.). This pain is localized and accompanied by sharp or throbbing sensations that will be familiar to most technicians.

Visceral pain originates from the internal organs and its associated sensations differ significantly from pain sensations in the somatic body. It is less localized than somatic pain. Animals may experience nonlocalized burning or aching in the abdomen or thorax, or pain may be referred to other areas of the body (i.e. shoulder pain associated with visceral tissue injury) ch0012-c2-bib-0003. Visceral pain can be challenging to detect as the source of pain is often much less apparent to observers when compared to somatic pain. A technician can easily see when an animal is limping due to a fractured leg, but they cannot easily see intestinal injury on a physical assessment. Technicians should consider visceral pain if there seems to be indistinct or inconsistent painful responses on physical assessment. Clinical signs or laboratory results associated with organ dysfunction should also lead the veterinary team to consider the possibility of visceral pain affecting that organ.

sect2.title: 2.2.2 Acute vs Chronic Pain
sect2.para: Adaptive pain is what we generally refer to asacute pain . It occurs immediately in response to a painful stimulus (e.g. trauma, surgery, or inflammation) and is of short duration (generally hours to days). The severity of acute pain varies depending on the nature of associated tissue damage ch0012-c2-bib-0004. Nociception proceeds normally in instances of acute pain, and it is more straightforward to manage. Poorly managed acute pain has the potential to become maladaptive ch0012-c2-bib-0005.

Chronic pain is the term most often associated with maladaptive pain. The classification of chronic pain by a specific duration is somewhat arbitrary ch0012-c2-bib-0004. It occurs when pain persists beyond what would be expected with the nature of the initial acute tissue injury. Chronic pain does not serve as a normal protective mechanism for the animal and is pathological. Chronic pain is often overlooked as the affected animals learn to function in its presence. For example, cats suffering from osteoarthritis may show no overt clinical signs or only subtle signs of the disease (e.g. reduced jumping ability).

End‐of‐life patients often suffer from chronic pain but may also have bouts of acute pain due to a new injury or illness or a complication associated with an existing diagnosis. For example, a dog with osteosarcoma may suffer a pathological fracture of the affected bone. The pain in this situation would be described asacute‐on‐chronic. Acute‐on‐chronic pain may also be referred to as breakthrough pain . An example of this would be an arthritic dog that experiences breakthrough pain after exercising too much and exacerbating inflammation in the affected joints. These animals will require additional interventions to manage the change in their pain.

sect2.title: 2.2.3 Neuropathic Pain
sect2.para: Pain that is severe, persistent, or poorly managed can cause physiological changes throughout nociceptive pathways. These maladaptive neurophysiological changes cause what is known asneuropathic pain . Sensory receptors are upregulated, neural connections and excitatory neurotransmitters increase, and inhibitory neurotransmitters decrease. Maladaptive changes in nociception make it easier for the body to sense and perceive pain. The nervous system in these patients is hypersensitized or “primed” for pain.

Neuropathic pain can occur with diseases that affect the nerves themselves but commonly results from severe pain or chronic pain that has not been well managed. It is challenging to diagnose because animals cannot communicate directly with observers and this type of pain can produce some unusual sensations. Human patients with neuropathic pain describe feeling burning, stabbing, or even numbness and tingling ch0012-c2-bib-0004. Patients with neuropathic pain may experience pain from stimuli that would otherwise not be painful (allodynia), or pain responses may be heightened compared to what would be expected for a given stimulus (hyperalgesia). Neuropathic pain should be considered and regularly addressed in EOL patients.

sect2.title: 2.3 Pain Recognition
sect2.para: Understanding nociceptive pathways and the types of pain can help technicians recognize and interpret physical and behavioral indicators of pain. These indicators form the basis of pain assessment tools that may be used to evaluate pain in EOL patients. As mentioned in the previous section, acute pain is generally easier to observe, whereas signs of chronic and neuropathic pain can be more subtle (Pro Tip 2.1).
Physical signs of pain are often straightforward to identify when the technician assesses an animal. Common physical indicators of pain are included inTable 2.1.

Behavioral changes are the most common signs of pain in animals and include both decreases in normal behavior (e.g. decreased activity, decreased appetite, etc.) and increases in abnormal behaviors (e.g. aggression, inappropriate elimination, etc.)ch0012-c2-bib-0006. This can be directly related to the physical impacts of pain and also due to the cognitive and emotional impacts of pain, particularly chronic pain. Behavioral indicators can be more difficult to recognize than physical indicators as the signs can be subtle (e.g. sleeping more, moving less, etc.) and are often mistaken for something else by caregivers (e.g. lack of energy and activity may be ascribed to “getting old” rather than pain). Technicians must consider pain when any of the behavioral indicators from Table 2.2 are present in EOL companion animals.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 2.1 Stress, Cortisol, and Chronic Pain
sidebar.para: Multiple physiological changes are associated with chronic pain due to persistent elevations in blood cortisol from the related stress. These may be less obvious to technicians in a pain assessment.

listitem.para: Decreased immune function (i.e. increased risk of infection, impaired healing)
Gastrointestinal signs (i.e. ulceration, nausea, vomiting, impaired digestion)
Hypertension
Dull coat

Behavioral indicators of pain can vary significantly between individuals and between species. Technicians will need to familiarize themselves with normal behaviors for the species they are working with and ask the caregivers for information on what is normal for their individual pet. There may be behavioral indicators of pain relevant for the individual that go beyond what is listed above.

sect2.title: 2.3.1 Fear, Anxiety, Stress, and Pain Recognition
sect2.para: Fear, anxiety, and stress (FAS), a phrase used in FearFree™ training ch0012-c2-bib-0007, can complicate the assessment of pain in animals. As discussed, the most common sign of pain in animals is a change of behavior. When animals are stressed, they are evolutionarily adapted to hide their pain which makes assessment challenging. Some of the physiological changes that are expected with pain may also occur in stressed animals due to the activation of their sympathetic nervous system (fight, flight, or freeze). Physical changes such as elevated heart rate and blood pressure make it difficult for technicians to discern between stress and pain, especially when a combination of both may be present in the patient (Figure 2.2).

sect2.para: Minimizing FAS in EOL patients leads to more accurate pain assessment, which results in better pain management and improved QOL. This is a key reason why it is preferable to perform EOL consultations and follow‐up care in the home environment as much as possible. The animal will be less stressed in their home and the assessment of their pain will be more accurate. In addition to prioritizing home care, further stress reduction strategies may be implemented such as the use of calming pheromone products, fear‐free handling techniques, or even antianxiety medications (seeChapter 4 for further discussion of anxiety management in EOL patients).

sect2.title: 2.4 Pain Assessment Tools
sect2.para: The use of thorough and objective pain assessment tools that are familiar to the user can make the challenging task of pain assessment much more manageable. Technicians should keep in mind that there is an element of subjectivity in all pain scoring, as well as interobserver variation although some tools are more objective and reliable than othersch0012-c2-bib-0008. Multiple pain scales and scoring systems have been developed for companion animals. This section will examine several commonly used tools with attention to their advantages, limitations, and appropriate applications.

Pain scales may be either simple or multidimensional in their construction and use. Pain is complex and simple scales may not provide sufficient information to effectively assess pain, particularly in EOL patients who may be experiencing multiple types of pain. Simple scales also tend to be more subjective in nature compared to multidimensional tools. Multidimensional pain scales are more comprehensive and tend to be more objective than simple scales. These tools combine physical and behavioral indicators of pain to examine multiple aspects of the clinical presentation of pain. Many pain scales are designed specifically to evaluate acute pain, and while they may be useful for acute‐on‐chronic pain, they are less appropriate for the assessment of animals experiencing chronic pain. Veterinary teams must identify which tools are most appropriate for their purposes and become familiar with them to improve reliability between assessments both within and between observers.

sect2.title: 2.4.1 Simple Pain Scales
sect2.para: Simple pain scales can be designed with numeric ratings, visual analogs, or descriptions to assess pain (Figure 2.3) ch0012-c2-bib-0001. These scales are all subjective, lack interobserver reliability and do not account for animals that are being affected by fear and stress (which can obscure or mimic some signs of pain). Veterinary teams will need to collect more objective information alongside these assessments before pain management interventions can be prescribed. Their use in EOL care is discouraged in favor of multidimensional pain scales, but they have been included as they are easy to use and may have value in limited circumstances where other tools present accessibility or other compliance challenges for the caregiver.

listitem.para: Numeric rating scales ask observers to rate the animal’s pain, usually out of 10, where zero is no pain and 10 is severe pain. This may be done verbally, which is common in human medicine, or using a visual scale with numbers and simple descriptors plotted along a horizontal line [ch0012-c2-bib-0001, ch0012-c2-bib-0009].

Visual analog systems consist of a horizontal line of known length with no pain at one end and the worst pain at the opposite end. The user simply marks the scale with their perception of the animal’s pain, and the technician can measure where the caregiver marked the scale to document a score. There are no other descriptors or numerical subdivisions [ch0012-c2-bib-0001, ch0012-c2-bib-0009].

Simple descriptive scales utilize descriptive terms and/or images that help the user determine if the patient fits into categories of pain such as none, mild, moderate, or severe [ch0012-c2-bib-0001, ch0012-c2-bib-0009].

sect2.title: 2.4.2 Multidimensional Acute Pain Scales
sect2.para: A brief description of acute pain scales has been included for the assessment of acute‐on‐chronic pain in EOL patients. As previously discussed, acute pain scales are not designed or scientifically validated for the assessment of chronic pain (seePro Tip 2.2). Technicians will use caution when interpreting the results of acute pain scales in EOL patients with suspected or known chronic pain.

At the time of writing, the scientifically validatedFeline Grimace Scale (FGS) ch0012-c2-bib-0010 is a common preferred choice of veterinary teams for the assessment of acute pain in cats. Multiple facial features are used to evaluate pain including ear position, orbital (eye) tightening, muzzle tension, whisker position, and head position. The FGS is an objective pain assessment tool for feline patients that has the added benefit of a less invasive approach, as direct handling of the patient is not required (Figure 2.4). Grimace scales are also available for a limited number of other species (Pro Tip 2.3).

TheGlasgow Composite Measure Pain Scale (CMPS) is a validated tool for assessing acute pain with canine and feline versions published. The canine scale evaluates multiple indicators of pain including vocalization, attention to painful areas, response to palpation, mobility, posture, and response to surroundings ch0012-c2-bib-0011. The feline version is similar with the addition of an assessment of facial features, albeit notably more simplified than the FGS.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 2.2 Scientific Validation of Pain Scores
sidebar.para: For a pain scoring system to be scientifically validated, it must meet several criteria in a controlled experimental study. The tool must be able to effectively differentiate between painful and nonpainful patients (accuracy), and the results must be consistent with repeated evaluations from the same and different observers (reliability).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 2.3 Grimace Scores for Multiple Species
sidebar.para: Grimace Score Systems are being developed for multiple species. Grimace scores are available for cats, mice, rabbits, rats, ferrets, horses, and likely more species in the future.

sect2.para: TheColorado State University (CSU) Acute Pain Scale ch0012-c2-bib-0012 has been developed for dogs, cats, and horses. Users assign numerical pain scores with the help of images and descriptions related to body positioning, physiological and behavioral signs, response to palpation, and overall body tension. There is some scientific evidence to support its use in cats, but neither the canine nor feline scale currently meet the standards for scientific validation ch0012-c2-bib-0013. The CSU scales can be excellent teaching tools to help veterinary staff and caregivers recognize pain in animals, so they may be of value in EOL care beyond the assessment of breakthrough pain.

sect2.title: 2.4.3 Multidimensional Chronic Pain Scales
sect2.para: The multidimensional chronic pain scales that are used in veterinary medicine tend to be focused on osteoarthritis, as it is a highly prevalent cause of chronic pain in companion animals. Four chronic pain scales validated for use in dogs are listed belowch0012-c2-bib-0014. Any of these tools may be used in EOL patients experiencing osteoarthritis. EOL care teams will identify their preferred tools while including contrasting options that may appeal to different caregivers’ needs.

listitem.para: TheLiverpool Osteoarthritis in Dogs (LOAD) ch0012-c2-bib-0015 is a moderate length questionnaire completed by the caregivers. Its multiple‐choice questions cover medical history, lifestyle, and mobility details ranging from the duration of clinical signs and tolerance of exercise to the impact of weather and terrain. It is meant to be accompanied by a veterinary consultation, but the questions are simple and approachable, and detailed instructions are provided to guide the veterinary team in administering and interpreting the questionnaire.

TheCanine Brief Pain Inventory (CPBI) (Figure 2.5) ch0012-c2-bib-0016 is shorter than LOAD and formatted with questions answered on a numerical scale of 1–10. It is arguably less comprehensive than LOAD but is scientifically validated and may appeal to caregivers and the EOL care team due to its brevity and simplicity. Questions ask the caregiver to rate their dog’s pain and its impact on mobility and QOL. The final question asks the caregiver for their overall impression of the dog’s QOL. (The utility of global QOL scores will be discussed in Chapter 5). No guidance is given as to how to interpret the score and this would be left up to the veterinary team.

Figure 2.5

listitem.para: TheHelsinki Chronic Pain Index (HCPI) ch0012-c2-bib-0017 is somewhat comparable to the CPBI as a simple survey of questions answered on a five‐point scale. It focuses on mobility and QOL without directly asking the caregiver for their subjective assessment of the level of pain. No guidance is given as to how to interpret the score, and this would be left up to the veterinary team.

TheCanine Orthopedic Index (COI) ch0012-c2-bib-0018 is more structured than the CPBI or HCPI. It is divided into four sections: stiffness, mobility, gait and QOL. There are 16 questions that caregivers answer on a descriptive scale with five options. As with the CPBI and HCPI, there is no guidance offered in the tool of how to interpret or act upon the score and this would be up to the veterinary team.

sect2.para: The variety of tools available for feline chronic pain assessment is more limited but there are two validated tools available, both focused on osteoarthritis.

listitem.para: TheFeline Musculoskeletal Pain Index (FMPI) ch0012-c2-bib-0019 is a survey that asks caregivers to rate their cat’s behavior and mobility with a scale of five descriptive responses. It is very straightforward and easy for caregivers to complete, although no guidance is provided on how to interpret the results.

TheMontreal Instrument for Cat Arthritis Testing (Mi‐CAT) [ch0012-c2-bib-0020, ch0012-c2-bib-0021] is published in two versions, one for the caregiver and one for the veterinary professional. The veterinary assessment includes an evaluation of posture, gait, mobility in the face of obstacles, and an overall distant impression of mobility. There are detailed instructions and images to guide the veterinary professional in the assessment. The caretaker assessment is a simple questionnaire with questions answered yes, no, or unsure. Instructions are given to determine a total score, but no guidance is given on how to interpret the final score. The Mi‐CAT is significantly more complex than the FMPI, but the increased complexity may offer more information and stimulate more discussion than the FMPI.

sect2.para: The scales described above all focus on osteoarthritis in companion animals, and other validated pain scales in the scientific literature are also disease specific (e.g. spinal disease) and cannot be broadly applied in EOL care. With that in mind, an unvalidated multidimensional pain scale has been included for technician consideration, which was created by certified hospice and palliative care veterinarian, Dr. Shea Cox: theBEAP Pain Scale (Figure 2.6) ch0012-c2-bib-0022.

While the BEAP Pain Scale is not scientifically validated, it has a combination of features that can be advantageous for use in EOL, particularly in educating caregivers about potential indicators of pain. The combined use of descriptive and numerical scales with corresponding images is most similar in format to the CSU acute pain scales but is more comprehensive. Both canine and feline versions are available. The acronym BEAP represents the items included in the scale: breathing, eyes, ambulation, activity, appetite, attitude, posture, and palpation. The scale is organized in 10 levels from 0 (no pain) to 9–10 (worst pain possible), with descriptions for each BEAP item at every level. The caregiver marks the description that best matches their pet for each item. Guidance is provided to interpret the scoring (e.g. pain score 3–4, moderate pain, see your vet to assess pain). The tool also offers space for the caregiver to further describe what they are seeing for each BEAP category. Despite the lack of scientific validation, this tool may offer caregivers a better understanding of the multidimensional nature of pain and is likely to collect important information for the EOL care team.
Apply your knowledge of the indicators of pain and pain scales toCase Study 2.1 to reflect on your understanding of pain assessment.

sidebar.title: Case Study 2.1 Barley
sidebar.para: Barley is a 12‐year‐old, neutered male, domestic shorthair cat. About 18 months ago, he stopped jumping on counters and was having bowel movements outside the litter box. He also had less interest in playing with some of his favorite toys. He was diagnosed with osteoarthritis and started on nonsteroidal anti‐inflammatory drug therapy. His behavior and activity improved dramatically according to the caregiver.

In the last few days, Barley’s caregivers have reported that some of the behavioral concerns have recurred. Barley is also lethargic with a decreased appetite and is urinating and drinking more than usual. Physical examination reveals the following:

listitem.para: Heart rate 200, respiratory rate 40, and temperature 39.0 °C/102.2 °F
Drooped whiskers, ears slightly downward, and eyes slightly squinted
Stressed and hiding in his kennel at the veterinary clinic
Head hanging and hunched posture

sect2.title: 2.5 Practical Pain Assessment
sect2.para: The initial assessment of pain must always occur in the context of a veterinary consultation and will include evaluation of both physical and behavioral indicators of pain. Technicians should document respiration rate and effort as well as a temperament assessment before any direct handling. Any items of the pain score that can be evaluated without direct handling should be completed before a physical assessment is begun. This is to prevent FAS and sympathetic activation from obscuring the results.

Pain should be re‐evaluated regularly and each pain score documented in the medical records. This allows the veterinary team and caregivers to monitor for response to treatment and trends over time. Some of the pain scales have an explicit threshold at which re‐evaluation of the treatment plan and intervention is recommended. The veterinary team and caregivers must establish a framework to determine when pain score changes will trigger re‐evaluation and possible intervention within an individualized treatment plan. Proactive monitoring by the technician and caregivers can help to identify changes such as breakthrough pain, which allows fast intervention to minimize pain crises and neuropathic pain, and support QOL.

In the EOL context, we often rely on caregivers to record observations such as pain scores at home between veterinary visits. Consistent use of the same tool is important for caregivers to develop familiarity with the tool which improves accuracy and reliability for monitoring pain trends. With that said, caregivers may require flexibility in the initial selection of a tool that is most accessible for them as an individual. A technician may provide the tool with the most scientific evidence behind it, but if the caregiver finds it too difficult or overwhelming to use then they will not use it effectively. It is advisable to introduce more than one pain scale (no more than 2–3) and demonstrate their use. The caregivers can try them out and let the technician know which one they prefer. The best pain scale in the world is no good if the client does not use it! Once a pain scoring system is selected that will meet the needs of the EOL care team, patient and family, then it is of utmost importance that its use is implemented and continued regularly. That leads to the question of how frequently should a pain scale be used to evaluate EOL patients?

Recommendations for the frequency of pain scoring must be determined on a case‐by‐case basis and may vary from monthly or bimonthly to multiples times in a single day. A patient in the early stages of hospice care may not be experiencing significant progression or change. This patient may be well managed with once or twice monthly pain scoring until any noticeable changes trigger a re‐evaluation sooner. A patient receiving advanced hospice care with many changes occurring may need to be evaluated multiple times in a week or a day. The frequency of pain scoring will be decided in discussion between the caregiver and veterinary team. Any time a change in the animal’s physical state or behavior is noted, a pain assessment is recommended. Any time there is a change in the treatment plan, a follow‐up pain assessment is recommended to evaluate the impact of the intervention. The technician plays an important role in communicating the plan and following up as caregivers monitor pain at home (Pro Tip 2.4).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 2.4 Home Pain Scoring Routines
sidebar.para: The frequency of pain scoring will vary between cases and within cases depending on the patient’s status, veterinary recommendations, and caregiver limitations. Ensure the chosen pain scale is approachable and accessible for the caregiver. Follow up and provide support to improve compliance with pain scoring at home. Suggest a way for caregivers to keep track of the pain scores for their own reference (i.e. a journal or calendar) and make a plan for them to provide this information to the EOL care team.

sect2.para: An excellent strategy to improve caregiver compliance with pain scoring is to offer a more comprehensive pain assessment tool paired with a more simplified approach to document impressions of QOL between more thorough pain assessments. The comprehensive pain scale can be used on a determined schedule (i.e. monthly or weekly) and when there are patient concerns or treatment changes. A simpler QOL assessment can then be used more regularly (i.e. weekly or daily) for documenting patient trends at home (seeChapter 5 for further discussion of QOL assessment).

sect2.title: 2.6 Caregiver Communication and Education
sect2.para: Skilled and knowledgeable veterinary technicians are excellent patient advocates, client educators, and communicators. Technicians can empower caregivers of EOL pets with information and skills that allow them to be more active partners in their pet’s care. Techniques for building effective communication skills will be discussed further in Part II.

Caregiver education should always be supported with resources that the caregiver can refer to when the veterinary team is no longer present. This may include physical or digital copies of information handouts, pain assessment tools, and items such as links to online instructional videos. A written copy of the pet’s treatment plan should also be provided to caregivers. It will ideally include descriptions of the most likely behavioral and physical indicators of pain for their individual pet, recommendations of how often to complete pain and QOL assessments, and the method to communicate that information to the veterinary team. Comprehensive, multidimensional scales should be utilized for pain assessment wherever possible. This is easy to do when the evaluator is a veterinary professional but can be challenging when caregivers are asked to use the same tools. Caregivers may require significant education and support from the EOL care team to feel comfortable applying these tools to their pets at home. It is well worth the effort on the part of the EOL team to provide this support.

Avoid overwhelming caregivers with too many options for pain assessment tools, while still offering flexibility in identifying tools that they are comfortable using. If there is more than one caregiver, each caregiver may feel comfortable using a different pain scale. This can even be advantageous, as the assessments from multiple observers can be compared to offer multiple perspectives on the pet’s pain. Different caregivers may see different parts of an animal’s daily routine. So even if caregivers choose the same pain score system, it can be helpful for each caregiver to complete it separately and then discuss where their assessments overlap and differ.

Interested caregivers may also be empowered to record certain elements of a physical assessment, such as respiratory rate. There are elements of a physical assessment performed by veterinarians and technicians that are not reasonable for most caregivers to perform (e.g. cardiac auscultation or abdominal palpation), but there are elements that caregivers can be taught to perform if they are willing and properly trained (e.g. taking heart rates by palpating the apex beat and recording respiratory rates by watching the rise and fall of the chest). Assigning simple physical assessment tasks to interested caregivers can improve the quality of in‐home monitoring, offer the veterinary team more information between visits, and give caregivers an increased sense of control and active involvement in their pet’s care. This can help to relieve some of the anxiety caregivers may feel during the EOL journey.

sect2.title: 2.6.1 Caregiver Myths and Misconceptions
sect2.para: Technicians knowledgeable about pain and skilled in pain recognition can help dispel some myths and misconceptions about pain for caregivers. Statements such as those below are often heard from caregivers who might be in denial about their pet’s pain, or who simply lack an understanding of the multidimensional nature of pain.
“My pet is not in pain because …
… they are still eating.”
… they still wag their tail when they see me.”
… they still greet me at the door whenever I get home.”
… they don’t whine or cry.”

Caregivers' own experiences with pain (or lack thereof) will also impact their perception of pain in their pet. For instance, a person who has never experienced an infected tooth or bone fracture may not be able to relate to the pain those conditions can cause. Conversely, if a person has experienced painful conditions but they fail to see the signs that they experienced in their pet, they may falsely believe that their pet is not in the same pain they felt. Until they receive education about the signs of pain in animals, caregivers may miss the subtle indicators that show the impact of pain on their pet. For this reason, there should be a concerted effort to educate caregivers on the signs of pain proactively rather than reactively (seePro Tip 2.5).

Technicians encountering challenges with caregivers’ comprehension and recognition of signs of pain may inquire about the caregiver’s perspectives and experiences with pain as it can help guide conversations about pain in a more directed fashion. This can also be important when it comes to caregivers expressing concerns about administering treatments. Caregivers may be hesitant to administer prescribed treatments if they perceive there is a potential harm from adverse effects of pharmaceuticals, or if they fear that the administration will be stressful. Technicians cannot address these concerns if they do not know about them. Seeking the client’s perspective is key, both at the time of starting into an EOL care plan, but also as the implementation and impact of the plan on both patients and caregivers is evaluated. Helping caregivers recognize pain and understand and agree that there is a need to intervene is the first step. This can be followed by thorough discussion of the risks and benefits of treatments and exploration of multimodal analgesic options, including nonpharmaceutical modalities which is the subject ofChapter 3.

listitem.para: Technicians who understand the physiology and classification of pain can more effectively recognize and assess pain.

Pain scales are useful tools for pain assessment when chosen with thought and intention and used regularly and appropriately.Pro Tip 2.5 Early Client Education on Indicators of Pain
Practices may consider the routine inclusion of pain recognition resources for caregivers of senior animals. Educating caregivers on the signs of pain BEFORE they occur will facilitate early recognition and intervention to improve quality of life. Share information on pain recognition in the reception area, exam rooms, on the practice website, and on social media. Improving the awareness of the signs of pain in caregivers of animals in all lifestages can only be beneficial.

Technicians with developed knowledge of pain recognition and assessment can communicate with caregivers and advocate for their patients more effectively, thereby improving QOL and supporting the human–animal bond.
Caregivers can be active members of the EOL care team empowered to evaluate and monitor pain in their pet between veterinary visits.
